primary_content.title: What We Test
primary_content.description:
Structural heart devices correct valvular dysfunction through transcatheter delivery, requiring validation that demonstrates precise deployment in beating hearts while preventing paravalvular leak, coronary obstruction, and conduction disturbances. Transcatheter valve platforms must achieve accurate positioning within diseased native valves or annular structures while maintaining stable anchoring forces throughout 200-400 million cardiac cycles. Edge-to-edge repair systems demand controlled leaflet grasping without tissue damage while LAA closure devices require complete sealing preventing thrombus formation. Each platform category presents unique deployment challenges from calcified aortic valve navigation to D-shaped mitral annulus conformability.

We evaluate deployment precision using high-resolution fluoroscopy and echocardiographic imaging that captures device positioning, expansion symmetry, and interaction with surrounding structures throughout complete delivery sequences. Our catheterization laboratories feature pressure-gradient measurement systems, Doppler flow analysis, and contrast imaging protocols quantifying paravalvular leak severity, coronary flow preservation, and hemodynamic performance. Specialized anatomical models replicate patient-specific valve pathologies including bicuspid aortic anatomy, functional mitral regurgitation, and challenging LAA morphologies. Durability testing protocols simulate years of cyclic loading through ISO 5840 accelerated wear assessment.

ISO 5840 heart valve standards guide structural and hydrodynamic testing while FDA guidance documents for transcatheter heart valve systems inform protocol development addressing deployment characterization, durability requirements, and biocompatibility assessment. Our GLP-compliant testing supports PMA pathways for Class III structural heart devices. Whether validating next-generation balloon-expandable valves, self-expanding platforms, or novel repair technologies, our protocols demonstrate deployment accuracy, hemodynamic performance, and chronic durability that regulatory submissions demand.

capabilities.title: Deployment Precision and Positioning Assessment
capabilities.description: High-resolution fluoroscopy and echocardiographic imaging characterizes device deployment accuracy, expansion symmetry, and anatomical positioning while quantifying reposition capabilities, retrieval success rates, and final implant stability across varying valve pathologies.

capabilities.title: Paravalvular Leak Quantification and Sealing Assessment
capabilities.description: Doppler echocardiography and contrast imaging protocols measure regurgitation severity through standardized grading while pressure-gradient analysis quantifies hemodynamic impact. Specialized protocols assess sealing effectiveness against calcified tissue and anatomical irregularities.

capabilities.title: ISO 5840 Durability and Accelerated Wear Testing
capabilities.description: Cyclic loading protocols simulate 200-400 million cardiac cycles representing 5-10 years of valve function while monitoring structural integrity, leaflet motion, and hemodynamic performance degradation. Accelerated testing identifies failure modes and validates design improvements.

capabilities.title: Coronary Flow Preservation and LVOT Assessment
capabilities.description: Selective coronary angiography evaluates ostial obstruction risk while computational flow modeling predicts coronary access maintenance. Left ventricular outflow tract evaluation quantifies gradient changes and obstruction potential following mitral interventions.

capabilities.title: Tissue Interaction and Chronic Integration Studies
capabilities.description: Histopathological analysis characterizes tissue response at device-valve interfaces, endothelialization progression, and fibrous encapsulation patterns. Leaflet grasping studies for repair devices assess tissue damage, healing, and long-term durability.

capabilities.title: Conduction System Impact and Rhythm Monitoring
capabilities.description: Continuous ECG monitoring throughout chronic studies detects conduction disturbances, new bundle branch blocks, and complete heart block requiring permanent pacing. Proximity mapping identifies high-risk anatomical relationships with atrioventricular node.

cards.title: Structural Heart Device Expertise
cards.description: Founded by Duke University interventional cardiologists who pioneered transcatheter structural heart procedures, our team understands complex cardiac anatomy, deployment mechanics, and chronic tissue integration requirements. This cardiovascular heritage translates to protocol designs that address FDA Class III device requirements including anatomical compatibility demonstration, endothelialization assessment, and comprehensive safety validation across diverse patient anatomies and pathologies.

cards.title: Proven Structural Heart Regulatory Success

We understand Class III device requirements including chronic biocompatibility demonstration through ISO 10993 compliance, deployment accuracy validation, and the specific endpoints FDA expects for structural heart device submissions across valve replacement and repair applications.
